text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES,
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.
Your full name William James Forsyth.
Present Address Corningdale, Sask.
Pioneer Address Eagle Creek, Sask., 1904.
Year you came to Saskatchewan 1903.
(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1924, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

MILITARY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? None until 1906.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? About two thirds.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Usually only on business.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? No.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? 2

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Anyone present at meal time was always invited to eat.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Come and get it.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Coffee, tea, etc.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes - often.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Dances - sometimes shooting matches ending with a dance at night.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. Yes.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? During winter months, dances were held at different homes regularly.
1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 

2. How many of these were bachelor's homes? 

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday or other days? 

4. Have you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? 

5. What time of the day did you go in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? 

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? 

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe. 

8. Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. 

9. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? 

10. During winter months, dances were held at different homes regularly.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? Not till the early twenties.

What material was it made of? Lumber. How large was it? 30 x 60

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Community Volunteer Labor.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Village.

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school houses as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

The hall was used for all gatherings.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? Yes.

How were babies and small children provided for? Babies and small children were put to sleep in beds made up of blankets.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? In closets.

11. What card games were popular in the early days? King Pedro.

Was there card playing for a prize? No.

What dances were popular? Square dances, Waltzes, two steps, Polka.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. No.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Some approved this form of entertainment and some did not.
6. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, etc., and other activities. Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc. If you have not described these on the School Questionnaire, give dates.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? Not till the early twenties.

What material was it made of? Lumber.

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Community Volunteer Labor.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Village Hall.

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you ever think to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.)?

The hall was used for all gatherings.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10), did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for? Babies and small children were put to sleep below the floorboards.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time so those parties could be held? Horses were always sheltered and fed.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular? Square Dance - Waltz - Two Step.

Was there ever any disreputable between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Some approved this form of entertainment and some did not.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes.

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

Chivarees were common, usually ended up with a supper and dance.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc. that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Changes were noticeable when railroad came through — social activity did reform we used to know them died out.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Canadian Order of Foresters - 1929.

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes.

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

1918.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

Nearly all

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? No.

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What attempts at formalizing or "vouk," do you remember in small towns, such as Elora and Bath when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?

13. Was the chivalry known in your community? If so, describe what you remember about chivalry, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

Changes also noticeable when Mildred came through — social activities died out.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and given by private individuals. Remember you can when some changes in visiting or social life become noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

1918.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space on the sheet questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? No Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Ball

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? Both
What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? If so, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? If so, give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   *skating, sliding.*

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   *checkers, dominoes.*

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   *Work took up most of the time.*

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

**PLINICS AND SPORTS.**

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?  
   Give year and month, if possible.  
   *Community field at old Eagle Creek bridge, on Battleford trail.*

26. Who organized it?  
   *In June 1905, dance on the bridge at night.*

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   *Community.*
   
At that time there were no schools.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
   *Yes*

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   *Horse shows tug o war, pony races, children races, basket supper.*

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   *Sandwiches, baked lemonade.*

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   *9 p.m., till six in evening.*
22. What winter games were played outside? (fox and hounds, baseball, etc.)

What games were played indoors in winter? (card games such as "Happy Family," checkers, or other games)

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children have games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, stones, or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICTURES AND SPORTS

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?

Give year and month, if possible.

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? At what time? Where was he school?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, etc.)? How about tug-of-war, pony races, children's races, basket supper.

30. What arrangements were made for eating? Was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Sandwiches, baked beans, etc.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

The dance on the bridge was novel and entertaining.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnics, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

Picnics were held at Millet's Crossing annually. There had a large attendance, entertainments included horse racing, football, tug-of-war, children's races, relay races, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Ball - Horse shoe - foot-ball -
Horse races - ox races - potato races

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Foot ball -

What year? 1913. How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

Baseball team. Played against teams at Sunningdale, Longhorn, Aquith, Perdue, Beaver Creek

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.)

1945 - Skating -

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Curling rink built in 1951.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

The dance on the field was wonderful.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large annual town picnic, school picnic, family picnic, etc., etc., when held, etc., etc.

Picnics were held at Milly's Cemetery. Annually

Then had a large attendance of amusement included. Horse racing, foot ball, tug-of-war, children races, relay races, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Ball - Hand - Foot-ball - potato races

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

First ball

What year?

1913

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, flying dates of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger contests, etc.

Baseball team. Played against teams of Springfield

Longhorn Aquatic - produce brown track

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.)

Then was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Curling rink built in 1915
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1937
Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? Yes
When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st). July

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)
Bible-

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. 40

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? Yes When was it begun? 1916
To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
7. When did an annual "report day" become established in your community? Did it grow out of or replace the earlier "community picnic"? Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? When was the sports day usually held? (What Fourth, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 4th?)

11. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known football, basketball, or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible; if not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy any books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun? To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school textbooks as additional reading material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started? Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

   Saskatoon Phoenix

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
59. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Who started it?

60. Was it still in existence? If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

61. Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

52. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to this area?

53. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

54. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages or reading material? Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

55. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

56. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? Mouth organ.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Violin, banjo.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them. Piano, accordion, guitar.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

in the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? No When was it started?
Who started it? How long did it continue?
How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?
What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

55. What musical instruments did you bring when you moved here?

56. What musical instruments did any of your neighbors have?

57. What instruments did you buy since you came to the area? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

58. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years? Describe.

59. Was there a band in your community? If so, describe its activities, how often practice was held, what uniforms the members had, etc.

60. Were there musical concerts, parties, etc.? Describe.

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where,
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

General

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
10. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the past few years? Give names and dates and places of public appearance.

64. Is there an important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

BUSINESS AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

65. Do you have any collections, such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you began, what interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.? Explain.

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music, etc., not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary.)
Oxford
